reinforcements.similarity: Both elements address the identical problem: the platform displays financial information in nightly rates while users think in monthly budgets. The existing library element (host-side) establishes the single-sum financial display principle: show one total in the host's native format (monthly rent) before any breakdown. The new guest-run element (works-005) independently arrives at the same conclusion from the guest's perspective: front-load pricing transparency by showing monthly equivalents and seasonal rate ranges.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: The host call (andreas-call.txt, 3:02-3:16) shows the host thinks in monthly sums. The guest call (nneka-call.txt, 03:33-04:26) shows the host references rates as '$1,170-$1,175' monthly. Both Kahneman references (bat-and-ball problem) confirm that over 50% of people fail nightly-to-monthly arithmetic. This is now validated from BOTH sides of the marketplace. The pricing format mismatch is the single most pervasive design problem in the entire platform, confirmed by two independent lenses.

reinforcements.similarity: Direct reinforcement of the single-sum financial display principle. The existing library element prescribes one large number in the user's native format with conversion shown as secondary annotation. The new guest-run element prescribes the identical hierarchy for the guest side: monthly cost equivalent at primary weight, nightly rate as explanatory subtitle, full breakdown on demand.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library element evidence: host processes pricing as sequential additive sum (andreas-call, 3:02-3:16). New element evidence: listing page shows three simultaneous financial figures ($300.98/night, $3,611.79/4-week, $11,738.32 total) that force System 2 arithmetic. Kahneman's bat-and-ball research applies identically to both host and guest. This reinforcement elevates the single-sum principle from a host-journey pattern to a universal platform design rule.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address ego depletion across multi-step processes. The existing library element (Design for the Depleted User) prescribes smart defaults, save-and-resume, and decompression moments for the host journey. The new guest-run element (Stays Manager as System 1 Dashboard) prescribes restructuring the most-visited page to minimize cognitive load on depleted hybrid workers who visit weekly.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kahneman's parole judge study is cited in both: depleted decision-makers default to denial. The host equivalent is abandoning the listing wizard. The guest equivalent is abandoning the Stays Manager check-in or reverting to off-platform communication. Both elements share the same theoretical foundation but apply it to different journey phases and different user roles, extending the depletion-aware design principle to cover the full lifecycle.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the gap between conversational interaction speed and platform interaction speed. The existing library element prescribes matching the platform's cognitive speed to the phone call. The new element prescribes eliminating off-platform communication by making the platform faster than texting for date changes.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas describes two units in 7 seconds of speech; the platform must match this density. New evidence: Brad texts Nneka to reschedule because a text message takes 10 seconds while the platform has no equivalent fast path. Both use Kahneman's law of least effort as the theoretical basis. The combined insight is: the platform must compete on speed not just with the phone call (host-side) but also with text messaging (guest-side) as the benchmark for interaction efficiency.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address notifications as continuation mechanisms rather than interruptions. The existing library element prescribes notification-as-continuation for the host journey (notifications feel like the next thing Bryant would say). The new guest-run element prescribes the proposal pipeline as an anxiety-resolving status stream with push notifications that resolve uncertainty.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: the phone call ends with personal promises (email follow-up), so notifications must feel personal. New evidence: Brad texts Nneka because no notification system tells him what happened (nneka-call.txt, 01:23-01:42; Bryant at 08:40-09:07 confirms notifications are being built). Both use Kahneman's System 2 activation during uncertainty as the theoretical basis. The combined insight: notifications are not a feature -- they are the primary mechanism for preventing off-platform communication on both sides of the marketplace.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the System 1 trust gate at transitions and critical moments. The existing library element prescribes passing System 1's automatic assessment at every phase transition (visual consistency, familiar language, explicit connection to prior phase). The new guest-run element prescribes self-service date changes at conversational speed within the Stays Manager -- which is itself a System 1 design principle (meet the guest where they already are, in the page they already visit).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: each phase transition must signal continuity. New evidence: the date change flow must live inside the Stays Manager (the page the guest already visits weekly) to avoid a context-switch that triggers System 1 reassessment. Both use Kahneman's associative coherence principle. The combined insight: System 1 continuity applies not just to phase transitions but to every micro-interaction within a phase -- even tool access points must feel like extensions of the current context, not new contexts.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the emotional architecture around financial information. The existing library element (Relief of Guaranteed Income) addresses the host's need to see their money and know it is safe. The new guest-run element (Price Surprise Shield) addresses the guest's need to never encounter an unexpected price change that feels like betrayal.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: hosts need to see guaranteed income to feel relief. New evidence: Nneka reveals seasonal pricing changes ($1,170-$1,175 to higher rates) that create mid-lease price shocks for the guest. Kahneman's anchoring and loss aversion research applies to both: the first number becomes the reference point. The combined insight: both host and guest anchor on the first financial number they see, and deviations from that anchor produce negative emotional responses regardless of objective fairness. The platform must manage anchoring from both sides simultaneously.

reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe a single-number financial focal point at primary visual weight. The existing library element establishes the visual pattern: one large figure using Outfit bold at oversized font, with supporting numbers at secondary weight. The new guest-run element applies the identical visual principle to the guest's listing evaluation, proposal, and payment schedule views.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: the host needs one number (monthly rent equivalent) at 28-36px bold before any breakdown. New evidence: the guest needs one number (monthly cost equivalent) at 28px bold before the nightly rate or total is shown. Both cite the bat-and-ball problem and Kahneman's attention-and-effort research. The typographic hierarchy (3:1 size ratio between primary and secondary financial figures) is independently prescribed by both elements, validating the ratio as a universal platform standard.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address depletion-aware pacing through the emotional arc of repeated interactions. The existing library element prescribes the host journey should feel like a stroll, with decompression moments after high-effort phases. The new guest-run element prescribes the Stays Manager emotional arc across 13 weeks: warm guidance early, efficient data mid-lease, grateful acknowledgment at close.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Both use Kahneman's cognitive ease gradient and System 2's 'natural speed' (a comfortable walk, not a sprint). The host-side insight: decompression moments between phases prevent cumulative depletion. The guest-side insight: the Stays Manager must EVOLVE its emotional tone across 13 visits, matching the guest's increasing familiarity. The combined insight: depletion-aware design is not static -- it must adapt over time as the user's relationship with the platform matures.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address proposal presentation. The existing library element prescribes pre-packaged proposals for the host (confirm, don't construct). The new guest-run element prescribes the proposal progress pipeline for the guest (show who acts next, expected timeline, and what happens next).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Bryant presents the tenant arrangement as a nearly-done deal the host can confirm with minimal effort. New evidence: after the guest submits a proposal, they enter an anxiety-producing waiting state with no visibility into progress. Both use Kahneman's System 1/System 2 distinction: confirmation is System 1 (effortless), construction/monitoring is System 2 (depleting). The combined insight: proposals must be optimized for BOTH sides -- easy to accept for the host AND transparent in progress for the guest.

contradictions.conflict: The existing library element specifies warm off-white backgrounds (bg #f6f4f0) and white surface cards (#ffffff) as the universal visual foundation, with forest green (#2d5a3d) as the accent. The new guest-run elements introduce a different color vocabulary: --secondary-purple, --status-warning-light (#FDF4E3), --status-success-light (#E6F5EE), --bg-light (#f9fafb), --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6). The new elements reference Inter and Outfit fonts, while the library specifies Instrument Serif, Outfit, and IBM Plex Mono. The purple accent and the gray-blue background tones (#f9fafb, #f3f4f6) may conflict with the warm neutral palette established in tokens.json.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The tokens.json file is the authoritative source. It specifies bg: #f6f4f0 (warm off-white), accent: #2d5a3d (forest green), and Instrument Serif / Outfit / IBM Plex Mono as the type stack. The new elements reference tokens (--secondary-purple, Inter font, --bg-light-gray) that do not exist in tokens.json. The library's color and type specifications align with tokens.json; the new elements introduce an alternative vocabulary that may come from a separate style guide or design system document not yet reflected in tokens.json.
contradictions.recommendation: The new guest-run elements should be reconciled with tokens.json before merging into the library. Options: (1) Add the new tokens (--secondary-purple, --status-warning-light, --bg-light) to tokens.json if they represent intentional extensions of the design system. (2) Translate the new elements' color references to existing token equivalents (e.g., --secondary-purple may map to accent or accent-bright; --status-warning-light may map to signal-warn-bg). (3) Replace Inter font references with the established Outfit sans-serif from tokens.json. The new elements' visual logic (hero card elevation, status badge color coding, financial hierarchy) is sound -- the conflict is in token naming, not in design intent.

contradictions.conflict: The existing library element prescribes the agent's identity as the primary trust frame across all platform communications (every notification comes FROM the agent, the platform speaks as an extension of Bryant). The new guest-run listing card element (communicates-006) prescribes schedule-first listing cards where the primary signal is schedule compatibility, with host name/info relegated to quaternary position. This creates a tension: the library says the human agent should be the most prominent trust signal on every screen, but the new guest-run search results deprioritize the host's identity in favor of functional matching data.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The library evidence is from the host onboarding journey where trust transfer from Bryant is critical. The new element evidence is from the guest search phase where functional fit (schedule compatibility) is the primary decision driver. These are different journey phases with different cognitive priorities. In the host journey, the agent IS the trust bridge. In the guest search, the agent is irrelevant -- the guest is evaluating listings, not building a relationship with an agent. The library principle (agent as trust anchor) is correct for host-facing screens but should not be mechanically applied to guest-facing search results.
contradictions.recommendation: Clarify that the agent-continuity-frame principle applies to the specific user's assigned agent relationship, not universally to all screens. For guest search results, the relevant human signal is the host's verification status (a trust badge), not the Split Lease agent's identity. The host's name and verification badge are appropriate at quaternary hierarchy on listing cards, while schedule fit and pricing are primary. No contradiction exists if the principle is scoped correctly: agent identity is primary for the user who has a personal agent relationship (the host); listing-level trust signals (host verification) are appropriate for the guest evaluating multiple listings.

extensions.gap_filled: Self-service date change flow for active_lease phase -- the most critical missing infrastructure in the guest journey. No existing library element addresses in-platform schedule management. The existing library focuses on host onboarding and listing creation; this element fills the gap for the guest's most frequent interaction (weekly date management).
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Directly evidenced by the Nneka call (Brad texting to reschedule, Bryant confirming the tool is being built) and the journey map (Date Change section exists in UI spec but lacks guest-initiated flow).

extensions.gap_filled: Financial legibility of replace/add/remove date change types. No existing library element addresses the semantic and financial distinction between change types. This element fills a gap in the pricing display architecture by extending the single-sum principle to micro-financial decisions within the active lease.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Directly evidenced by Bryant's confusion about replace vs. add pricing (nneka-call.txt, 07:22-07:45) and Nneka's inability to honor old rates for rescheduled dates (03:33-04:26).

extensions.gap_filled: Stays Manager restructured as a System 1 weekly dashboard rather than a System 2 management console. No existing library element addresses the design of the most-visited page in the platform. This fills the coverage gap for active_lease guest experience.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. The journey context (Layer 0) identifies the Stays Manager as the 'most visited page, weekly returns.' Kahneman's skill acquisition and cognitive ease research directly supports the hero-card-over-table restructuring.

extensions.gap_filled: Batched administrative tasks (reviews, photo uploads) to prevent ego depletion cascade during active lease. No existing library element addresses the review fatigue problem. The library's depletion-aware design (works-002) addresses multi-step process completion but not the long-term administrative burden of a 13-week recurring interaction pattern.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The evidence is based on Kahneman's ego depletion theory applied to a 13-week review cycle. No direct call evidence that guests actually experience review fatigue -- this is a theoretical extension. However, the design principle (batch administrative tasks at natural reflection points) is well-grounded and low-risk.
extensions.confidence_note_2: Strengthened by the Layer 0 identification of hybrid workers as the primary guest persona, whose cognitive budget for platform administration is minimal.

extensions.gap_filled: Real-time availability surfacing inside the guest's decision flow. No existing library element addresses the Airbnb cross-listing availability dependency that creates opaque rejection patterns. This fills a critical search and active_lease gap where the guest's success depends on a system they cannot see.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence. Directly evidenced by Nneka's Airbnb cross-listing confirmation (05:06-05:44) and Bryant's workaround of asking for availability screenshots (05:27). The availability opacity problem is well-documented but the solution (real-time sync surfaced in every date-related view) has significant technical implications beyond UI design.

extensions.gap_filled: Current-week hero card information architecture for the Stays Manager. Extends the library's anchor-then-advance principle (communicates-001) to a recurring weekly context rather than a one-time onboarding flow.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. The hero card inverts the flat table to match the guest's weekly micro-interaction pattern. Evidence is strong from both the journey map (table structure) and Kahneman (cognitive ease for repeated tasks).

extensions.gap_filled: Pre-commitment rate anchoring -- showing seasonal rate variability before the guest locks a single rate in memory. Extends the library's single-sum principle to account for multi-season leases where a single rate is misleading.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Nneka's seasonal pricing revelation ($1,170 to higher rates) directly evidences the anchoring trap. Kahneman's anchoring and Muller-Lyer illusion research provides strong theoretical support.

extensions.gap_filled: Schedule-first listing cards for guest search results. No existing library element addresses the guest search experience or listing card hierarchy. The existing library is entirely host-journey focused; this element fills the guest search gap with a design informed by the platform's unique value proposition (schedule-based matching).
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. Bryant's description of schedule matching as the core challenge (10:17-10:27) and Nneka's rejection of schedule-mismatched guests (10:41-10:53) provide strong evidence. However, the listing card redesign has significant implications for the existing search UI and may conflict with visual patterns optimized for property-first browsing.

extensions.gap_filled: Three-tap contextual date change flow that competes with text messaging speed. No existing library element addresses interaction patterns for in-lease schedule management. This fills the behavioral gap for the guest's most frequent action during active_lease.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Brad's texting behavior (nneka-call.txt, 01:23-01:42) directly evidences the need. Kahneman's law of least effort provides the benchmark: the platform flow must be faster than composing a text message.

extensions.gap_filled: Notification-driven re-engagement system for guest journey. Extends the library's notification-as-continuation principle (behaves-006) to the guest side, with specific implementation patterns for deep-linking, coalescing, and contextual highlighting on arrival.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Bryant explicitly confirms notifications are missing and being built (08:40-09:07). Brad's texting behavior is direct evidence of the gap notifications would fill.

extensions.gap_filled: The text message temptation -- making the platform feel emotionally easier than informal channels. No existing library element addresses the emotional competition between formal platform tools and informal text messaging. This fills a gap in the active_lease emotional architecture specific to the guest persona.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Brad's texting preference (01:23-01:42) is direct behavioral evidence. Kahneman's law of least effort applies to emotional load as well as cognitive load -- the insight that 'casual' feels easier than 'formal' is well-grounded.

extensions.gap_filled: Discovery promise calibration -- setting honest expectations at first contact that survive the reality of mid-term housing negotiation. No existing library element addresses guest-side discovery messaging. The library's trust architecture (communicates-003) addresses trust credentials but not expectation management at the discovery touchpoint.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The evidence is theoretical (Kahneman's priming and associative coherence applied to discovery messaging) with indirect support from the Nneka call (Brad's rescheduling friction reveals the gap between 'flexible housing' promises and reality). No direct guest discovery data exists.

extensions.gap_filled: The invisible system -- designing for the 90% of visits where nothing needs the guest's attention. No existing library element addresses the emotional design of routine, nothing-is-wrong visits. The library focuses on engagement-driving interactions; this element addresses the equal importance of non-engagement moments.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. The hybrid worker persona (Bryant at 10:17-12:17) establishes that the guest's Monday morning check should take under 5 seconds. Kahneman's System 2 'natural speed' (a stroll) provides the theoretical foundation. The insight that 'silence is confidence' is a valuable extension of the emotional design framework.

new_tokens_flagged: --secondary-purple (not in tokens.json; possible mapping to accent #2d5a3d or a new purple accent)
--bg-light (#f9fafb) (not in tokens.json; cooler than bg #f6f4f0, may conflict with warm palette)
--bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) (not in tokens.json; cooler gray, may map to bg-deep #eae7e1)
--text-dark (#1a1a1a) (not in tokens.json; close to ink #1a1714 but cooler)
--text-gray (#6b7280) (not in tokens.json; cooler than ink-soft #4a4640 or ink-muted #8a857e)
--text-light-gray (#9ca3af) (not in tokens.json; may map to ink-ghost #bdb8b0)
--border-color (not in tokens.json; may map to border #e2dfd9)
--shadow-sm / --shadow-md (referenced by variable name, present in tokens.json by value but not by CSS variable name)
--status-warning-light / --status-warning-text (not in tokens.json; may map to signal-warn-bg #fef3e2 / signal-warn #c17a28)
--status-success-light / --status-success-text (not in tokens.json; no success color defined)
--status-error-light / --status-error-text (not in tokens.json; may map to signal-danger-bg #fde8e8 / signal-danger #b83a3a)
--white (#ffffff) (not explicitly named in tokens.json; surface #ffffff exists)
Inter font (not in tokens.json; tokens specify Outfit as sans-serif)
--spacing-2xl (not in tokens.json; spacing goes up to xxl at 60px)
--icon-xs (not in tokens.json; no icon sizing tokens defined)
--opacity-disabled (not in tokens.json; no opacity tokens defined)
--easing-ease-out / --transition-slow (not in tokens.json by these names; easing.out and easing.spring exist by value)
token_compliance.recommendation: The new guest-run elements introduce approximately 17 tokens not present in tokens.json. This is a significant token drift that must be reconciled before merging elements into the library. Recommended actions: (1) Map cool-gray tokens (--bg-light, --text-gray, --text-light-gray) to warm equivalents from tokens.json (bg-deep, ink-soft, ink-ghost) to maintain the warm palette integrity. (2) Add success status colors to tokens.json (signal-success and signal-success-bg) as they are needed for the guest journey but missing from the current token set. (3) Decide whether --secondary-purple is an intentional new accent or should map to the existing accent green. If purple is intentional, add it to tokens.json with a clear usage rule. (4) Replace all Inter font references with Outfit (the established sans-serif). (5) Add icon sizing, opacity, and CSS variable naming conventions to tokens.json to prevent future drift. (6) Ensure all new tokens use the warm-tinted color philosophy established in looks-001 (library): shadows use rgba(26,23,20,...) not rgba(0,0,0,...), grays trend warm not cool.

journey_emotion_map.source: feels-006 (guest run): honest expectations that survive contact with reality. The guest should feel 'this platform is telling me how it really works.' Target emotion: trust formed through specificity, not marketing.
journey_emotion_map.coverage: thin -- only feels-006 addresses discovery directly, and it is medium-confidence theoretical extension

journey_emotion_map.source: communicates-006 (guest run): schedule-first listing cards reduce wasted evaluation effort. The guest should feel 'this platform understands my schedule and shows me what works.'
journey_emotion_map.coverage: thin -- only one communicates element addresses search; no emotional element directly covers search feelings

journey_emotion_map.source: communicates-002 + communicates-004 (guest run): one-number financial legibility and pre-commitment rate anchoring. The guest should feel 'I know exactly what this costs and what might change.'
journey_emotion_map.coverage: moderate -- financial clarity is well-covered; emotional response to photos, rules, and host trust at listing level is not addressed

journey_emotion_map.source: behaves-003 (guest run): inline financial consequence preview before commitment. The guest should feel 'I know what I am signing up for.'
journey_emotion_map.coverage: thin -- the financial preview is covered but the emotional experience of committing to a proposal (anticipation, mild anxiety about acceptance) is not directly addressed

journey_emotion_map.source: feels-003 (guest run): resolving proposal anxiety through status visibility. feels-002 (guest run): preventing price-surprise betrayal. The guest should feel 'I know who is acting, when to expect a response, and what changed.'
journey_emotion_map.coverage: strong -- the waiting ache (feels-003) and price surprise shield (feels-002) together cover the two primary emotional risks in negotiation

journey_emotion_map.source: Layer 0 journey context identifies acceptance as medium-risk: the guest needs final terms verification. communicates-005 (guest run) addresses the pipeline reaching acceptance. The guest should feel 'I have a place to stay, and the terms are what I agreed to.'
journey_emotion_map.coverage: thin -- no dedicated emotional element for the acceptance moment; the pipeline element (communicates-005) covers the process but not the emotional celebration of securing housing

journey_emotion_map.source: Layer 0 identifies move-in as low dropout risk but high priming risk. The guest's emotional state is determined by cumulative priming from all prior phases.
journey_emotion_map.coverage: none -- no elements from any layer directly address move-in emotional design. This is an identified gap.

journey_emotion_map.source: feels-001 (weekly glance evolving across 13 weeks), feels-004 (text message temptation -- ease over formality), feels-005 (administrative guilt elimination -- lightness), feels-007 (invisible system -- freedom). The guest should feel 'this platform knows me, respects my time, and gets out of my way.'
journey_emotion_map.coverage: strong -- four dedicated emotional elements cover the full active_lease emotional range, from weekly routine to administrative burden to platform invisibility

arc_conflicts: The discovery phase targets trust through honest messaging (feels-006), but no visual or interaction element supports this emotional goal at discovery. The guest's first visual impression has no dedicated design element -- the library's warm-surface-continuity (looks-001) was designed for host onboarding, not guest discovery. There may be a visual tone gap at the guest's first touchpoint.

The acceptance phase targets relief and confirmation, but the emotional arc jumps from 'patience and assurance' (negotiation) directly to 'belonging and ease' (active_lease) without a dedicated emotional relief moment at acceptance. The pipeline element (communicates-005, behaves-004) covers process visibility but not the emotional celebration of 'I got a place to stay.' This is a missed emotional peak that could drive referral behavior.

The transition from proposal_creation (commitment/anticipation) to negotiation (patience/assurance) involves a significant emotional downshift: the guest goes from actively configuring their ideal stay to passively waiting for a host response. No element explicitly manages this emotional transition. The pipeline's 'preview of stages before submission' (behaves-004, empty state) partially addresses this but does not fully prepare the guest for the waiting-state emotional shift.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc is strongest in the active_lease phase (4 dedicated elements) and negotiation phase (2 dedicated elements), reflecting this lens's primary focus on the Nneka call which centers on active-lease rescheduling dynamics. The arc is weakest at the journey endpoints: discovery and move_in have minimal or no emotional coverage, and acceptance lacks a dedicated emotional peak. The overall arc tells a coherent story of 'trust formation through transparency and ease' but has a notable valley at acceptance and a gap at move_in. The next lens should specifically target these under-covered phases. End-to-end, the emotional trajectory is: trust (discovery) -> efficiency (search) -> clarity (listing_evaluation) -> commitment (proposal) -> patience + fairness (negotiation) -> [GAP: relief] (acceptance) -> [GAP: confirmation] (move_in) -> belonging + freedom (active_lease). The two gaps are the highest-priority emotional design opportunities for the next run.

discovery.note: Only one emotional element addresses discovery, and it is a medium-confidence theoretical extension. No process, information, visual, or interaction elements target the guest discovery experience.

search.note: Schedule-first listing cards and day-of-week compatibility indicator cover the search experience from information and visual perspectives. Missing: process patterns for search filtering, interaction patterns for search behavior, emotional elements for search frustration/hope.

listing_evaluation.note: Strong coverage of financial display and pricing transparency. Missing: emotional response to listing photos and descriptions, interaction patterns for the listing detail page, trust signals for evaluating unknown hosts.

proposal_creation.note: Financial preview and pricing transparency well-covered. Missing: the emotional experience of committing to a proposal, the UX of the proposal configuration flow itself, the proposal summary design.

negotiation.note: Strongest coverage of any transitional phase. Date changes, financial legibility, off-platform communication, proposal pipeline, and status visibility are all addressed. This reflects the Nneka call's deep illumination of negotiation/rescheduling dynamics.

acceptance.note: Acceptance is addressed only as a terminal stage of the proposal pipeline. No dedicated process, emotional, or interaction element targets the acceptance moment specifically. This is a gap given that acceptance is where the guest secures housing -- a high-emotional-stakes moment.

move_in.note: No elements from any layer in this run address the move-in phase. Layer 0 identified move-in as low dropout risk, which may have deprioritized it. However, move-in is the transition from digital to physical experience and sets the tone for 13 weeks of active_lease. This is a significant coverage gap.

active_lease.note: Dominant coverage -- 22 of 35 total elements address active_lease. This reflects the lens's focus (Nneka call is about an active guest) and the journey context's identification of Stays Manager as the most-visited page. Coverage is comprehensive across all five layers: process, information, visual, interaction, and emotional.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The next lens selection should specifically target the discovery, search, and move_in phases, which have thin-to-no coverage in the guest journey. The Nneka call illuminated active_lease and negotiation powerfully but left the early and transitional guest phases under-examined.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Select a guest call that captures a first-time guest evaluating Split Lease (discovery and search) or a guest describing their first week at a property (move_in and early active_lease). Pair with a book extract on first impressions, decision-making under uncertainty, or the psychology of space/place.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The process patterns for proposal_creation (the guest configuring their ideal terms) and acceptance (the guest securing housing) are thin. Works elements addressed active_lease date management comprehensively but did not deeply cover the proposal configuration flow or the acceptance confirmation flow.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: The journey map describes a multi-step proposal configuration (duration selector, day-of-week selection, pricing review, submit). A process element should define how these steps are sequenced to minimize depletion. For acceptance, a process element should define what confirmation looks like when terms have been modified through negotiation.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: Token compliance issues: 17 new tokens were introduced that do not exist in tokens.json. The visual designer should reconcile these with the established palette before the next run generates more drift. Specifically, the purple accent and cool-gray tones need to be resolved against the warm neutral foundation.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Provide the visual designer with this token compliance audit and require that all new elements reference existing tokens.json values or explicitly propose additions with rationale. If --secondary-purple is intentional, it must be added to tokens.json with a usage rule that distinguishes it from the existing green accent.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The emotional arc has gaps at acceptance (no relief/celebration moment) and move_in (no emotional design). The experience tuner should create emotional elements for these two phases in the next run.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: The acceptance moment is where the guest learns they have a place to stay -- this should be one of the strongest positive emotional peaks in the journey. The current pipeline treats it as just another stage transition. Move_in is where the digital promise meets physical reality; the emotional design should prepare the guest for this validation moment.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The listing evaluation page information architecture needs deeper treatment. The current run addressed financial display (one-number legibility) and seasonal rate anchoring, but did not address how photos, amenities, house rules, host trust signals, and neighborhood information should be hierarchically organized for the guest evaluating a specific listing.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: The journey map describes the listing page as showing photos, nightly rate, 4-week rent, duration selector, day-of-week selection, and house rules simultaneously. An information architecture element should define the scan order, disclosure pattern, and cognitive load constraints for this high-stakes evaluation page.
